qas.question: Ancient civilizations often alloyed metals for what reason?
Red gold is made by combining gold with?
Around what time was the Archimedes' principle discovered?
Who shouted "Eureka!" while checking the purity of a crown?
Buyers were often deceived when precious metals were mixed with?
Who alloyed metals for utilitarian purposes?
What is produced when gold is alloyed with tin?
Ten is often added to what to make sterling silver?
Softer silver was used for what practical items?

plausible_answers.text: find a way to check the purity of the gold in a crown

qas.question: What was Archimedes commissioned to do in 250 A.D.?

context: Many <b5_0>ancient civilizations<b5_0/> alloyed metals for <a0_0>purely aesthetic purposes<a0_0/>. In ancient Egypt and Mycenae, gold was often alloyed with <a1_0>copper<a1_0/> to produce <b6_0>red-gold<b6_0/>, or iron to produce a bright burgundy-gold. Gold was often found alloyed with silver or other metals to produce various types of colored gold. These metals were also used to strengthen each other, for more practical purposes. Copper was often added to <b7_0>silver<b7_0/> to make sterling silver, increasing its strength for use in <b8_0>dishes, silverware,<b8_0/> and other practical items. Quite often, precious metals were alloyed with <a4_0>less valuable substances<a4_0/> as a means to deceive buyers. Around <a2_0>250 BC<a2_0/>, <a3_0>Archimedes<a3_0/> was commissioned by the king to <b9_0>find a way to check the purity of the gold in a crown<b9_0/>, leading to the famous bath-house shouting of "Eureka!" upon the discovery of Archimedes' principle.
